reviewText:
Early Access Review

Take on Mars is possibly one of the most unique concepts to hit the steam store in a while. It's a game, of sorts, but more than that, it's a tool for learning and understanding the challenges inherent in exploring a planet far removed from our own, as well as providing a toolbox to this end. A very well thought out toolbox at that, which includes a tech tree (recently added), Multiple survey sites, and even now includes Deimos.

You are placed in charge of the Mars Space Exploration Agency, provided a budget to build, launch and research landers, and rovers, and tasked with exploring and analysing scitentific points of interest. Completing these objectives nets you further funding. The game part comes from balancing the needs of developing technology and launching appropriate craft to the right sites.

Funding -is- tight here, so it's very easy to box yourself in on the first few tries whilst you get the hang of how it all works. For that reason I really, really advise that you read the tutorials, go and do a bit of research on the web, and study the tech tree. Work out what you need to build, and apply an objective based approach to proceedings. This is not a game for anyone who isn't extremely patient and willing to invest in a concept which as an open ended project, is very different from pretty much anything that's come before.

As a niche product though, it should be applauded, because Bohemia has created a genuinely unique experience, one that if you've the time, the will and the inclination, provides a richly rewarding and deep journey, digging into the historical background of the Red Planet, and mixing a subtle element of managing your technology whilst exploring and unearthing secrets as you go.

Early Access Review

It's your own Mars (and asteroid belt) Exploration Program simulator.

In the game you control probes or rovers in real time (unlike in real life, where their control sequences are preprogrammed, and in emergency they are automatically put in a safe mode). It isn't only about exploring Mars, but also its moons and asteroids. You can also operate rover on Earth.

The objectives are quite repetitive (ride there, shoot photos, analyze air, soil, rocks, take a sample, all this to get funds and unlock next levels of available hardware which you will send to Mars next), but it isn't a boring game. You need to be careful to not break the equipment (or wheels), and watch out for strong wind, as small rovers and probes are quite light and fragile. It's currently in active development, so some things may still change and a new content (like sample analyze results currently having a placeholder) will be added.

It's a great game for space geeks, people who like realistic vehicle simulators, and other people who want to view Mars from rover's perspective.

I have been playing this one on and off since the game first appeared on on early access. I really enjoyed the early stages but it there were a few bits that made it not quite right. But of course, it's early access. However I have to say that I have recently got back into the game and it has changed almost beyond recognition. The latest addition of multi player has added so much more to the game. I am sure other developers would have been tempted to release this as at the very least a paid for DLC.

It is still early access, the plan is full release in June, (I am writing this in Aril), and I think that all that needs to be done is a bit of polishing to make it a great game. That said, the way the game has developed in the recent months leads me to believe that there will be a lot more than just a bit of polish.

There are no aliens to try to kill or avoid, you need to eat, so you grow your own food; you can't do this till you have soil and water.; you can't get this till you have the right machines..... Oh, and your suit does not hold much oxygen. Run out at your peril!

One thing I would say, the controls are a bit hard to get to grips with. Rotating stuff to get it to line up has taken me ages!

I love the vehicles available and the workshop integration is great with some really interesting stuff appearing.

In the space program side of the game you can choose to run in real time or game time. Real time, as the name suggests, runs at the right rate and so when you are told 45 hours to research the next bit of kit you need you have to wait 45 hours. Perfect time to drop to multi player for a bit I think :-) With game time you can advance time so you can play as quickly as you want. You need to develop probes, landers and rovers to map Mars and test soil, rocks and atmosphere.

I must find Beagle-2 and give it a nudge to see if I can get it to start up :-)

So, yes I do most definitely recommend the game, it is great value, the devs are fantastic and all in all this is what early access should be like.

I've now spent over an hour trying to get into this game, but it's extremely unforgiving.

You start the game off with $3 million. Research can easily bring that down to $500 thousand. Basic probe missions net you $150 thousand, but you *need* at least $50 to start these.

Spent 30 minutes surveying Mars with probes these basic probes that I cannot control, taking pictures of the land. Ran out of money conducting research, and I could not afford to fund another mission (game over).

Spent the next 30 minutes restarting the game. Surveyed all of Mars and built up my funds, so I researched a controllable zero-G probe. Think of a quadcopter, for space. This was obviously more fun to survey things with, as you actually got to do something. Only problem is that if you are too sporadic with your in-flight maneuvers, then components break. Components break, you lose control of your $1 million probe (yes, these ones cost $1 million). Good news is that if you don't screw up, you net $1.5 million. Otherwise, you're pretty much screwed.

I spun my zero-G probe too fast, lost control of it, and went from $1.9 million to $900 thousand. Really really frustrating spending a half hour getting to this comfortable point, just to have it all fall apart because I held the Up-Arrow too long. It was then not worth the time to try and recover the funds.

I would love to continue this game, but the knowledge that the game assumes you have about playing it is too much to learn without hours worth of trial and error, which means restarting your game multiple times, which means taking at least 30 minutes to an hour or more to get back to where you were.

I DO recommend this game, I just don't know enough not to continue to get frustrated by it, so beware.

At this point, I cannot really recommend this game.

It started out as a Mars Rover/Probe game which is currently all you do in the campaign part of the game. It's mostly complete with some missing features such as science results, I think the rovers still never actually run out of power and last I played it, it was still confusing as to what type of science a POI actually wants you to do. The biggest problem is the amount of time it takes for a rover to get anywhere. Obviously the rovers are slow, but there's no auto navigation and while you can trick the rover into driving forward without having to press a button constantly, you have to keep correcting as the rover will constantly veer off course.

The second part of the game, where the focus seems to have shifted entirely is the manned section, which is very interesting in theory, but falls short in terms of actual gameplay. Everything you do as a Mars colonist is very buggy and clunky with physics going haywire at the slightest provocation. For example, I managed to take out a bulkhead out of the large vehicle when trying to open a door, decompressing myself in the process. This is in part due to the UI being tied to game objects, which require precise clicking and even though you can change from interaction with the center of screen dot and cursor you can move independantly of the view, the UI is inconsistent about which input it will accept.

Another issue I have with object interaction is handling basically anything - you pick up an object and when it's in your hands, you can control how far from your body you hold it by scrolling the mouse wheel, the rotate it with one key and rotate it in a different way by pressing a modifier button in addition to the rotation button. Most objects won't connect with another object unless they're position in a particular way and when you add the weird handling of objects, pile it on top of the physics you will probably watch the resource container you've been fiddling with fly off into the distant martian landscape.

Content is being added but I'm not even interested in trying it out any more because the underlying issues persist and it seems backwards to add interesting things without having a stable framework that would allow you to have fun with all the elements present. The game is supposed to be nearing the end of its development cycle and I don't see it changing much in ways that would make it fun to actually play.

In short the game has many interesting elements that are combined with clunky, buggy gameplay, making a potentially fun and interesting experience dull and annoying.

Here are a few things I've noticed while playing Take On Mars:

-Airlocks and other doors are broken.  Airlocks are intended to permit passage between exterior and interior spaces without depressurizing the interior, as opposed to depressurizing everything BUT the space between the two airlock doors.  And regular interior doors have a chance of depressurizng everything as well, even if the pressure on either side is safe.

-Damage to space suits is global, rather than on a per-instance basis.  In other words, if you damage the legs on your medium suit, then take it off and put on a completely unused heavy suit, the legs of the heavy suit are also damaged.

-It's insanely easy to get stuck in geometry.  Attempting to get unstuck is also risky, as the physics engine loves throwing players around at high velocities.

-Things that look like they should fit together don't.  For example, the corners of airlock corridors have the same radius as regular curved walls, but refuse to be attached to anything but airlock passageways.

-The editor is both difficult to use and completely undocumented.  There's no indication that snapping is even a thing in the editor, making it impossible to construct a base outside of the scenario itself.

-Mouse acceleration is ridiculous and impossible to disable, meaning that a movement of the mouse as small as a few centimeters can sometimes rotate the camera completely around three or four times. Great game, if you ever wanted to send rovers and probes to Mars (and Deimos), do scientific experiments and exploration there.
Graphics are immersive, physics realistic and parts of your rovers/probes may get damaged ... not only if you mishandle them, but also due to the sometimes violent martian weather.
Likewise, the experiments featured are all experiments that also are part of the real Mars rovers (like Curiosity).

They just took some deviations from reality with regards to the voyage to Mars (which is immediately ... no long space travel required) and with regards to research times 8which is measured in hours instead of years).

Also, you are able to steer the rover in real time ... with no delay between sender and receiver (as it would be in reality) ... the latter one is taken care of however, as they are currently developing a game mode, where you have to give your rover a batch of commands (like, turn around 30 degs, move forward, use RAD-Sensor and so on) which the rover / probe then executes ... even if it may result in its damaging or destruction.

Definitely a game I would recommend ... it is good now and it is getting even better

This simulation is outstanding. Unmanned (land + space) and manned sim, all in one.

I'm outraged at some negative reviews written by people with 3 hours of game on record. Early access means opportunity to improve the game before final release, so use it, instead of ♥♥♥♥♥ing about it. Intellectual dishonesty is despicable, as is insulting the obvious hard work behind this project. And no, I-m not paid by anyone.

The scientifc depth, the attention to realism, the gameplay, the graphics, everything testifies of the skills of the developing team, and their commitment to an ambitious and fascinating project. Kudos to them, also for their responsiveness to the community.

I am about to finish the space program, therefore haven't nearly explored the whole scope of the game, not even tried the manned or survival part of it. But I can already confidently say that even only with what I have seen now, this is well worth the money. The BETA is stable. And it has the potential to be, simply, a masterpiece. If a number of recommendations and ideas as presented by the community will be integrated in the final development the game, it can IMHO attain a level of unprecedented excellence.

Of course, this is not for adrenaline junkies. I process my mails, watch the news, and even manage some substantive discussion with my wife, while playing this (...).

But if you are into realistic space exploration, astrophysics, astronautics, (space) engineering, then do yourself a favor and support this project. Devs, don't give up. I know people want space zombies and stuff, but I-m not the only one enjoying and appreciating the scientific (and fun) dimension of your project.

Building my first large rover, landing it, navigating it through Martian terrain, and proceeding with a successful series of scientific tasks... that was freaking good.

The Zero-gravity probe is great fun too. Here too, the experience is very immersive, the wannabe astronaut in me has a hard-on when navigating the asteroid belt and getting, after a careful approach (prepare to see your vehicle shattered by debris, or crashed by your recklessness), to scoop dirt and more, while zooming out in the big black space.

Highly, highly recommended.

Current games: Silent Hunter 5 (heavily modded...), Verdun, and now ... Take on Mars.

Early Access Review

--For those wanting to just get to a hands on review skip to the secondary section.--

I have been watching and following, and in the past had time to help with hunting bugs and harassing the devs with copy pasted reports since it first came out on early access. Over time I have gotten to see this game grow more and more, thus expanding it's own potential. Take On Mars not only is a simulator, but an educational platform (Hence the wiki data you unlock in the Robotics portion.). With games like this, and Kerbal Space Program, I see a lot of potential for games to bring new challenges and focus to many forms of education in simulation that can even be utilized in classrooms to get kids interested in space exploration, physics, astrobiology, and aeronautics through adaptive and hands on learning.

I know it's been a long time, and yes the due date has been pushed back, and yes there are still bugs that need to be smashed. But in the end, Take On Mars will be a perfect platform for both simulation lovers, and Mars Enthusiasts as the work put into this makes it one of the most unique games currently in beta. Long strides have been made in gaming technology that opens up more intuitive and complex forms of learning and adapting to in game demands through user comprehension and skill. This game needs as much notice and support as possible.

------------------------------------------------Section Two--------------------------------------

Take On Mars is a game based on the research of Mars in understanding what is to be expected for human crews to work with. In the first portion you are able to utilize probes, lander, rovers, and advanced equipment to study the martian surface and gather real world intel based on scientific findings. In chapter two you will take the role of a surviving astronaut who has to survive on the surface through building and maintaining equipment (Chapter2 is still in development.)

Also there are singleplayer and multiplayer scenarios, along with an editor so that you can build your own scenario and upload it to the workshop. Along with this is the ability to easily mod the game files via the developer toolset if you're into that. This gives grounds so a lot of malleability to the game and what players can do with it. Overall, despite it being unfinished I have to give it a 8/10 for both the improvements, the dev team, and the uniqueness of the game. There are others sure, like Mars: Challenger, which is fun but not one I can honestly recommend.

All in all, Take On Mars is a gem, and to those wondering if it is worth buying I will say this:

If you don't mind putting in the effort to submit bug reports, push the game mechanics, and test different aspects of the game then yes, buy it and help the developers expand and debug more of it.

If you want something polished off the bat and are not patient or willing to aid in development, then no, and nor should you buy any game on Early Access because that is what it is for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a fan of the survival genre. I'm a fan of the science-fiction genre. Put those two together and you get Take on Mars.

While not completely finished, as denotes it's Beta Build, it is on it's way to becoming a remarkably accurate simulator (with obvious gameplay exceptions) of survival on Mars.

That being said... it does suffer similar problems to most Open World Sandbox games of the same ilk at the moment. Notably the 'nothing to do but survive' problem. At least in most scenarios. Take On Mars, however, seems to address this problem with the Scenario / Scenario Editor... you can utilise triggers, events, etc. to create a story arc style of play. From landing, base building, to extraction should you want it, and thus solve the major issues of the survive to survive most survival genre titles have.

What strikes me most about this game in either the Single or Multiplayer, is the emptiness. Some put it down as a Con, I put it down as a Pro... Mars is empty. There is very little to do there in reality, and this is refelcted somewhat by gameplay. However, the inclusion of science experiments, sampling, and more would add greatly to the overall experience.

You can 'fake' science with the previously mentioned Scenario Triggers, but this pales in comparison to what the developers could possibly do in terms of story arc.

Single Player - The Single Player Gameplay starts with what could be considered a 'modern space age' where you send probes, landers and rovers to Mars, Deimos, and even the Asteroid Belt. After 'completing' this portion of the campaign gathering all the outlined data under objectives, you are ready to launch your manned mission.

I don't want to spoil the storyline of this mission arc, but Mark Watney move over, there's a new King of Mars. And it is story driven, though limited in scope. Starting in one area, and moving to another. With no option to alter which starting area, nor where you head to.

If you're looking for a completely free-roam Open World Sandbox game, this one is not for you. If you're looking for a game that throws enough realism in your face to be accounted a 'true' survival game then this is the one for you.

The team seems dedicated to keeping updates flowing, and they do address problems with the product as they can.

The game has been in Early Access for a while, but this doesn't phase me in the slightest. Years in development is basically any title that has something unique about it, or needs to be built in a different way from previous titles. Comparing development times of a game like this to games such as Battlefield or Call of Duty wastes time, and mental energy. Building onto previously formulae (Battlefield, Call of Duty, <insert other franchise here>) will always be faster, easier, and more efficient than creating something new, and I prefer the effectiveness of Take On Mars to the fast development that would see it be a reskin of another title.

In conclusion, the game does have bugs, and some of its elements lack polish, but if the development team continues the way they are going it may well show a new way to experience survival that actually throws whatever it can at you to make you fail, without big green aliens, zombies, or other post apocalyptic horrors.

You do some science stuff in the space program, building custom landers and rovers and researching new technologies to unlock new parts for your vehicles. So if you like things that have something to with space exploration, this is a must have game for you, in my opinion. Also, if you read The Martian by Andy Weir and liked it, you'll probably love this game too.

Did you like the Martin?  Well with the scenario editing tools you can put yourself in Mark Watney's suit. That concept got me to buy the game early access 12/26/15.  I played with the existing campaigns, both the robotics and manned and then jumped into the scenario editor.

Robtics Campaign- Meh.. it will appeal to some and not to others.  Give it a shot and see if it is for you.  I do see the potential to use it to encourage kids as a learning game as well as the pure 'game' aspects.  Cool.  Not my cuppa but cool.  They are still working on it and it may become 'more' and I will poke my head back in later.

Manned Campaign- You start out as a lone survivor after a crash. Not much here at the moment and it ends after about 10 min, but it lets you see some of what is coming.

Scenario Editor- OMG.  This alone was worth the money for the game as it is now IMHO.  It is finiky. The controls are so sensative you may want to scream, it can and will crash your whole system (early access folks!), still fun.  It took very little time to put some cargo pods on the surface, put some goodies in them and make a lander at altitude with a screaming me inside.  A little brousing and soon I had triggers etc figured out.  Other players are posting some great scenarios so you can dive in and play without doing it yourself.

I can not wait until the game gets to the point you can start in orbit and transfer to a lander, pick a spot and drop. =)
Multi player looks promising if you like co-op building.

Issues?  Uh yeah.  Early access.  Not going to beat the devs up or bash the game.  I'll wait, and if they don't update etc I will edit to reflect (and bash them and the game).  Past exp with this publisher makes me think it won't be an issue.

I have had many issues with crashing but.. early access.
Textures and shaders will flub up and it needs a system reboot to correct.
Running memory monitoring software and even sitting doing nothing the game slowly eats more and more memory untill crash.. but *shrug* early access.

Overall I will say worth what I paid (on sale), and if you are a space geek and don't mind the issues with an early access title go ahead and get it now. If you expect perfection and polish wait a bit for some more bugs to be worked out so you will not feel cheated.

I'll cut to the chase, If you don't like taking time to do things in game (like 2 or 3 hours to do 1 or 2 tasks) or if you don't have patience, this isn't for you. However, if you're an avid fan of the exploration front of our lives, this might be for you. The pictures and previews of the game aren't excatly accurate, BUT one day will be. Personally, I think this game is amazing. Even in early access there is so much to do and so much excitement to be had in doing it. That being said though, I know there will be alot of people who disagree and straight hate this game. It's easy to understand why though. This game is for those who want to take their time and don't mind taking literally hours to do one little thing.

Now onto the bugs. Of course there are bugs, glitches and pieces of incomplete game, it's Early Access! what do you expect? There was a glitch I came across where (Because I was finishing up for the night and only just started on the scenario) I took off my spacesuit and exposed myself to the vaccume of space on the moon. While I was expecting a rather quick death, there was a noticable delay in the decompression of the small rover airlock (about 5 seconds). During the breath phase I closed the airlock but died. During the first scenario on Mars, I noticed there was a hole in the mountain. Now not the regular kind of hole but the one that let's you crouch under and walk inside the mountain. Simple incomplete texture.

While roving on Mars, It took multipul attempts to scan one area while clearly inside the atmospheric scan zone using the correct instuments.

There are also many parts of the training yet to be finished (which again, Early Access, it was expected).

All in all, This game has one hell of a lot of promise and potential, which I am excited to see released. there will be patches along the way and many MANY additions but I look forward to every single one of them. Sure it's rough around the edges, and I probably sound extremely forgiving for this game, but it's because I can see it will be amazing and fun.

Small area to target but you hit the nail on the head! Absolutely amazing work guys! I look forward to the future of this!

Take on Mars: The Real Mars Simulator...
Yes the first thing that comes to mind when I play Take on Mars is Gran Turismo. The game is very realistic and beautifully presented. However just like Gran Turismo it does get a little repetitive after a while.
The game is very well made. It is highly informative and gives you a good sense of experience in controlling a unmanned mission to Mars.
When I played it for the first time I found it difficult to understand. But after couple of hours of clicking to find the right screens I began to understand the idea of the game. This does make the main game difficult to play. There is a tutorial which you will need to read. Also researching technology in the game is not clear and difficult to understand. I hope in time that they will fix this. In the mean time you will need to explore the game itself as well as the planet Mars to understand how it works. If you do lose patients with the main game there are many single missions which will keep you occupied. They are all great fun and very informative. If you enjoy exploring then this is the game for you. You will visit actual locations on Mars, using actual scientific equipment to unlock the knowledge and mysteries of the big red planet.
Depending on your graphics card the detail is amazing. When exploring Mars you do feel very alone on this vast world. The highly detailed graphics and sound effects create a atmosphere which leaves you very isolated in the game.
The controls are awkward but I believe that was on purpose to add to the realism of controlling a remote control vehicle across space.

I do recommend this game but you will need to be a little patient at times on how to play it. The game is still in it early stages and the potential for this game is vast. I am personally hoping they add sci-fi missions like a manned mission to Mars or first contact with martians. At time of this review being submitted the developers are currently very active in listening to the players and improving the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planetary exploration sim for egg heads. For as long as I can remember I have had a fascination with earths red neighbour. Since a child I have watched and read all about the various probes and landers sent to Mars.  Heard all the stories, myths and theories surrounding that place. It won't be long now when we will see a real possibility of a human stepping onto mars for the first time even if it will be a one way trip.  Take on Mars has really surprised me. I was expecting some kind of open world Mars exploration game but oh it is so much, much more than that. So far I haven't even set foot on the place. I am playing the campaign which means I start my journey right at the beginning with simple probes and black / white pictures.
In this mode you literally live through the history of exploration on Mars. Each successful mission earns you money which you can then plough into research to create more advanced exploration vehicles. As you advance it opens up ever more complex missions for your landers to complete. The lander camera view and the rugged Martian landscape really make you feel like you are in mission control.  There are a ton of other things you can do in Take on Mars including scenarios and multiplayer. For less than £10 this early release is a real diamond in the rough. Its fairly stable and very playable. The sounds and visuals that accompany you on your adventure add to the atmosphere.

Take on Mars is not going to be for everybody. Its certainly not fast paced and the only action will come in the form of technical disasters or your astronaut suit running out of oxygen. For me though it gives me a chance to do something I will never experience. Its a wonderful journey about what has been, what is now and what is coming in the near future.

I hope the developers keep putting their love into this title because if they do it will be a superb finished product.

I'm not sure why this game has mixed reviews.  It's still in beta, people.  Does it crash?  Yes, but you can STILL progress and have a meaningful experience if you're patient and save often.  I can't speak for multiplayer at this point, but in the last week I've built a fully functional base by myself (I'm a fan of the manned missions) and was into full-fledged methane production (a very time-consuming compound to make in the game).

It's worth your time if you're a space/science buff and are looking for an immersive space exploration experience.  With the way that development is going now, it seems like when the kinks are worked out of this game it could be a real-life simulation of survival on the red planet...if NASA ever develops space suits that can be put on/removed by one person. That's how immersive it is.

It doesn't just stop at Mars, either.  You can send rovers or conduct manned missions to asteroids, the moon of earth and the moons of Mars (Phobos and Deimos).  The devs have thought of everything and the attention to detail is fantastic.  I'm eager to see what will come in future updates and the anticipated v. 1.0 release.

I highly recommend this game as long as the devs keep up the good work.

Have you ever wanted to be a truck driver? Or maybe a crane operator? Or a building engineer (janitor)?
Then this is the game for you.

Rather than strictly a survival game, this is a harsh environment (survival) in which you are the driver and manual labor needed to assemble a Martian base of operations.

Many bugs.
Holes to be filled. And they have been at this for more than 2 years.

Bohemia is doing the work with patches being released fairly regularly. There should be no fear of a game that has been in development for a long time. It is a sign of discipline that they do not rush a buggy POS out the door. More as if they have invited us along for the developmental ride.

I look forward to all that I can play with 40 to 400 million miles from home.
(Can you imagine how the data/telemetry transmission delays changing span would just drive you nuts? Half the year Houston is 20 minutes away and the rest of the time more than an hour)

Worst negative thought I have about the game is the price. I see this as a $20 ticket. The extra $2 seems a dig.

this game is Great! 8 out 10.

WARNING - do not play this game if you like action. There generlly is none unless you make a mistake in which case it can cost you plenty.

When you fire up the single player mode you are given the option of robotics or manned campain.
the robotics campaign is then further broken down into Quick Time or Real Time opions.

for the robitics campain you are tasked with launching probes and exploring Mars. An extensive tech tree alows you to use funds raised by completing objectives to research improved systems and rovers, that allow you to perform more complicated research.

Larger missions can raise more cash but it's easy to get into the situatuion where alll your money is riding on one mission, only for a random system failer to cause it to smash into the ground. especially with new tech. Driving around taking photo's and air samples makes up most of the early robotics game play with surface sampling and other tests entering  mid to late campain.

Driving a rover is good fun but it is easy to underestimate the weather and/or terrain effects and end up trailing bits all over the place. When bad weather stikes you can hide behind a rock and just hope that the thing survives. Unlike real operatiors you have the option to swich to other probes at any time.

The Manned campain is still under construction but is a planed to be a series of liked sinarios

Very pretty even at low settings.
Realistic locations and effects
Punishing single player campaigns (robotic - and maned)

con's -
Very SLOW paced.   low gravity enviroments punish rushed actions.
Robotics campain consists of doing the same thing over and over to raise funds.
realistic affects can lead to R.U.D. of your probes and rovers. (Rapid Unplaned Disasembaly).

NEW REVIEW.
Since I wanted this review to help anybody to take the decision if they should buy this game, I rewrote it in order to make it a better one thats worth reading. I only hope that my review helps you to make the right decision.

Well, to start with, the game will be loved by every fan of space exploration games. In this game you take the role of Mars colonization program and you basically do the following:
1.Choose how to spend the money you have by funding your scientist to find new technologies that are used to upgrade your equipment and by doing so, you slowly reach the point of being able to send humans on the red planet.
2.You control your landers, rovers, spacecrafts and later even humans. This is more or less what you do. Controlling machines so as to finish tasks and later humans in order to survive and explore Mars

Now about what it feels playing the game. If you seek action and adventure leave. If you seek to reach your adrenaline levels to the top leave. You won't like this game. But if you seek a calm lonely drive ithrough the Martians plains, then you are in the right place. If you don't like long rides from on side of a crater to the other just to collect and analyse some sand, this game is not for you.
I don't want to waste any more of your time so I will sum up. This is a game about space exploration fans, that would like to see how it is to explore for many hours Mars, and help mankind to achieve its next big step, colonising for the first time a planet. I don't want to spoil you any more of its content, so I will stop here.

I'm sorry for any mistakes I made, I am not a native speaker but I tried my best. If you think that my review is incomplete or false you are free to correct me down in the comments, and I would be really happy to correct any possible mistakes I have made.


I will tell you one more thing:
If this game was a woman I would marry her. And instead of a dog we would have a rover pet. On Mars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers say this will be released in February, and I have no idea how they think that will be possible. The unmanned portion seems mostly complete, but the manned portion needs at least another year. It's full of bugs and glitches, there is absolutely no tutorial, explanation, or guide anywhere, and it's lacking a lot of immersion. The bugs range from being unable to attach a power cable properly to being flung across the Martian desert because you stood on said cable the wrong way. With no explanation in-game, on the walkthroughs through Steam, or on any forum for the game, every feature is hidden until you stumble across it and major components of the game are difficult to work out. It took me three hours to figure out how to assemble a structure, and I still have no clue what any of the various utilities do. The immersion problem is one they definitely won't fix, though, because they seem pretty happy with what they have: you can hear your astronaut's breath and heartbeat. All the time. Very loudly. Right in your ear. He also can't move any faster than a slow stroll, even on Earth, and can only run ten or twenty meters before getting winded. On the Moon, you would expect to do some cool Moon-style walking like in the NASA videos, but he just casually strolls from one place to another. I got to night-time on Mars (difficult because it's 1:1 timescale and there's no way to advance time, like sleeping or waiting) and expected some sort of awe inspiring view, but it was totally unimpressive. I was more impressed the first time I got a craft into orbit in Kerbal Space Program. I have the graphics all maxed out on a mobile GPU and I get 60 FPS - that means you're not trying hard enough.

From my previous experiences with this developer, I know what to expect: a game with countless flaws that showed promise and is occasionally, for very short periods, brilliant. Arma was like that, Take On Helicopters was like that, and DayZ is like that. They're very ambitious, and that's admirable, but they have no tenacity, patience, or follow-through.

If you get it on sale, like I did, you'll have a fun ten hours or so before deciding to just wait for the full release. But seeing as how they say that'll be in February, I'd say you should wait until the patch/update schedule has slowed a bit, because there should be a lot of them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This review does not apply to the multiplayer aspect of the game.

This game sounds very attractive on paper, Sadly right now it's little more than a thematic tech demo. From a technical standpoint it's a great piece of software, but it's simply not engaging.

Usually games, even though they might be hardcore (Orbiter, Dwarf Fortress, even KSP) make you feel rewarded when you achieve your goals. Even when those goals are self-imposed, you have a sense of achievement.

Imagine setting out to land on Eve and take off in KSP, or gather enough diamonds in Minecraft to make yourself a full set of armor. The game knows nothing about your objectives, but it has built-in impedements that make you feel you are working for something, and the game is balanced in such a way that, the more crazy your objective, the more difficulties you will encounter. And besides that, you have different tools at your disposal, in a way that you feel you have the freedom to attack the problem from different angles.

Take on Mars feels like you are just following a fixed list of steps (missions are exactly that actually) in order to put a checkbox in your to-do list and move to the next item. You have very little room to improvise or be clever about how you approach the missions, and the hardships you encounter are just not interesting nor really challenging.

As someone who has spent hundreds of hours playing the hardcore space flight sim Orbiter I would never have imagined a game like this would bore me. But sadly it does.

The research tree is very rich, and the mechanics of building and deploying vehicles are rock solid. Perhaps the problem is the game is too linear for a sandbox.

I'd wait until the developers fulfilled their vision for the game completely before buying it. Wait and see mode.

Hello Gentlemen,

Just got Take On Mars by Bohemia Interactive, the early access is available for download on steam. Downloaded it, installed it and double clicked on play. Straight to the options menu and run in windowed mode and then changed my mind and put it back to full screen mode. The first screen that greets you is the Take On Mars menu with the usual game options and a spinning depiction of planet Mars. You can hold down the LMB and spin the planet around and see cool sounding names like - Syrtis Major and Elysium Planitia. A few clicks and the initial tutorial loads up.  Clicked on Real World Time and eventually I make my way to the Lab and Construction Building. Found myself pressing the 'Test Vehicle' panel & see the lander. I see different views and instruments, You see (not manipulate) the outside world. My first test ship wobbled like crazy and the wide angle and telephoto view quality, looked like they had purchased the same cameras used in the Blair Witch project. Maybe it's an early alpha thing? I think Bohemia are simulating the quality of video/pictures sent from Mars back to Earth -- lossy and crap. Like any man on the planet who has never read an instruction manual since making 1/32 Airfix models, I end up pressing every single key to see what screens pop up. Oooh... aaarghhh... what does that do... oohhh.... Esc key goes to Main Menu.  Yawn and fast forwarded to the Launch vehicle 13mins 39secs. Look around the crater for about six or seven minutes and then stumble on the list of tasks required to be completed in this particular mission.

After pressing every key again, q,w,e,r,t,y,,,,,. I find myself at the Capture Gas stage. oooh... aarghhhh.... Click on Capture Gas. Yay! DO NOT MOVE INSTRUMENT in flashing red text. First you capture the gas, then you analyse gas. (Insert Fart Joke) This is one of the Major Tasks completed at the initial first assignment Victoria Crater. Your initial foray in the Victoria Crater teaches you Mars atmospheric pressure differences compared to Earth and also the composition percentages of CO2, N & Ar (I knew learning the first twenty elements of the periodic table would be useful in my lifetime.. thanks to my grade 10 science teacher Mr Clewett). Once you complete a mission, you also get access to New Tech Levels and various vehicle and instruments at tech level 2 become available.  And I got a steam achievement unlocked It's All About the Science" I then read the rest of the Mission task and see there is another minor task
date: a photo opportunity requirement.\n\nThe light bulb dims and I figure out that mission tasks are comprised of Major task and Minor tasks. Each successful completion of Major & Minor tasks during a mission will allow you access to higher level tech and more cash to spend on stuff. In the Early Access version

Early Access Review

I really wanted to like this one, and it's coming along in leaps and bounds, but as it stands at the moment, there's not a great deal there.

The base game involves launching probes at map locations and watching them land. You'll do a lot of that until you can build up enough money to start doing more interesting things with rovers and landers.

The recent addition of the multi-player component adds a massive amount more to the game, giving you the ability to build your own little mars base and keep yourself alive... but it's definitely in its infancy.

Graphically it's lovely.  Gameplay... early stages.

If you like the idea of exploring Mars, and quite fancy the thought of building your own base there, then DEFINITELY keep this one bookmarked. However, I'd recommend waiting until there's a bit more development before getting too excited.

It has a lot of potential, and I'll recommend it on the strength of that alone.
